column2: Sir Alexander Fleming observed the bacterial-killing effects of penicillin in his laboratory in London. This was the first step in the discovery of one of the most important pillars of today's medicine: the antibiotics. It took many years to find a way to produce penicillin in large amounts
column3: and large-scale production did not start until 1945. However
column5: Fleming is considered the father of the antibiotics
column6: and without his discovery we could not treat many infections caused by bacteria. This means that
column8: even a small infected wound could become fatal. In addition
column9: surgery is much safer with antibiotics
column10: and people with weak immune systems (like children or elderly) can now easily recover from bacterial infections. However
column11: bacteria are becoming resistant to antibiotics
column12: which was also predicted by Fleming in 1945
column13: during his acceptance speech for the Nobel Prize.
